newsitem.title: UK: Aluminium tightness flares ahead of August date.
newsitem.headline: Aluminium tightness flares ahead of August date.

text.p: Backwardations for upcoming August delivery dates for aluminium flared up on Thursday on the London Metal Exchange (LME), as speculative and trade shorts scrambled for cover.

Technical tightness has been building up for some time now on the the LME, but Thursday saw a rush of covering - both by borrowing metal and by buying cash outright - with the crunch "third Wednesday" date trading next Monday.
"Clearly, people have been covering ahead of next week. They tend to do that nowadays, rather than leave it to the last moment," analyst Robin Bhar of LME trader Brandeis said.

In lively ring sessions the premium to borrow August aluminium for one day was at $11, against a backwardation of $17 in place for the whole week. This led to the cash/threes spread moving out to near $20 backwardation, having been level earlier this week.

Next Monday, the cash that is traded will be for the "third Wednesday" of August. This prompt is where volatility is nearly always focussed, as open interest gravitates to this date when it is traded as a forward position beyond three months.
Also, options that are declared on the first Wednesday of the month are for settlement on this day as well.
Floor traders said the tightness has been well-signposted, with bank interests said to be long, while speculative funds and natural trade hedge shorts are on the other side of the market.
Because of this backwardation, spare metal is now being attracted to the market. Consequently, LME stocks are starting to rise, with increases totalling 6,550 tonnes over the last three days.
"I don't think this is a trend yet...I think a bit of metal has been warranted to take advantage of August," a trader said.

On Thursday, there was the unusual occurrence of 3,075 tonnes delivered into LME Japanese warehouses. Since the LME recognised Japan as a delivery point, aluminium has rarely been stored in these warehouses.
The bulk of Thursday's increase was metal warranted in Yokohama, which is the port where the high tonnages of off-warrant aluminium are held in Japan.

As well as grabbing the backwardation, stocks may be filtering on to the LME as long-term consignment deals come to an end and because the contango has disappeared financing has become unprofitable, Bhar said.
Next Monday's cash trading is not expected to signal an end to the high premiums, as the whole of the month is starting to show signs of tightness with August/September at $30 backwardation.
Also, some positions may have simply been rolled forward three months from August, putting the heat on the November dates.
Meanwhile, traders do not expect the LME authorities to take any immediate action, following the Board's recent reminder to members of its rules regarding market conditions and abuse.

Some noted that cash/one day at $11 is well below a thereoritical $17 one percent daily limit. In copper, the LME has imposed this limit - based on one precent of the previous day cash price for the daily premium.
But no such limit exists in aluminium, and any action would have to be authorised by the LME Board, others noted.
"There is a lesson here that applies in copper and zinc as well - don't sell what doesn't below to you,' one senior floor trader said.
